reviewText:
This could be seen as one‚Äôs own adventure from the real world through to the forgotten realm‚Ä¶ Or it could also be seen as the tale of the foolish and selfish Empress Qora, or maybe it could be seen as just another home warming party.

As I open Qora I am surrounded by beautiful sound, a sound that brings me back to some games I played as a child not much older than a toddler. Right off the bat I am in love with the soundtrack. After being introduced to the magnificently well-made pixel art by the jolly men building my house, I become immersed in the life of this new town in which I now live, it lacks nothing, and every resident has his own personality and their own problems and fortunes. The town is as active as any I‚Äôve ever seen. The geography of the town is beautifully realized.

The story captivates you once you start the actual plot, with a lore ever so mysterious that keeps you playing in order to find out everything about it. You are a special person, and you didn‚Äôt know it until a statue told you so. I have the power to be a link between two worlds, our world and the world of our ancestors. It is my job to find out the truth about our world through their world. Temple-older-than-ancestors-themselves here I come. Will I actually learn anything? Maybe.

As I venture off in the outskirts of this beautiful world‚Äôs town, I realize I wouldn‚Äôt be able to progress without the help of some of the residents. I acquired a sweater a machete a pickaxe among other things. A fellow traveller is on the same journey as I am, though he lacks the ‚Äòsight‚Äô and therefore finds it emptier than I do. He wants ghosts, but only I can see them. However, he finds what he was looking for, while I endlessly keep on searching‚Ä¶

The smoothness of the gameplay is simply satisfying, and the sceneries never fail to impress, dropping my jaw each time I enter a new map. It is beginning to feel like a true love letter to classic RPG-Explorers, even if the linearity is strong. The feeling this game conveys is a complex one and difficult to understand, the link between present and past, between descendant and ancestor, it is a beautiful one, and I am beginning to think this is the initiation of an epic adventure.

The deeper I go, the more I fall in love. This is a place of wonder, a place of magic, a place of emotion, a place of companionship, a place of solitude, a place of war, and a place of peace.
Stories about love, stories about hate, stories about misfortunes, stories about silliness, stories about sacrifice, and stories about freedom. This game, is extremely human.

The soundtrack is what manages to complete the conveyance of whatever sentiment the developers are trying to achieve, and it does so extraordinarily. I personally loved every single minute of this game, and do not regret putting in 3 hours into it whatsoever.

This game brings a reality to grand adventures that is more thoughtful than pretentious.

There isn't much in the way of interaction. You move left, right, you climb, you jump and drop off of obstacles. Additionally you at times you need to hack some grass or crush a rock. Maybe even light an altar. A one button sort of affair. But it all has this sense of not being real.

Yes, this is probably not new. An Indie developed pixel art game that lends itself to an ‚Äúartsy-fartsy‚Äù(if you‚Äôll excuse the term) sense of being. However this one pokes fun at itself. The writing seems aware of the players doubt that this is totally pretentious and gives them a nod from time to time.

Despite the overwhelming knowledge that I was pretty sure I could not die and that every time I pressed space or down to perform the canned animation of jumping over a hole or dropping down from a ledge. I found myself staring at it. As if the tiny little maybe 8 pixel character was both struggling and simultaneously gallivanting through the world without a care. I was transfixed. Even though I had zero doubt that he would not be able to make the jump. Each time I pressed the button, I said to myself; What if he doesn't make it?

It takes around 1 hour and 45 minutes to complete. I recommend playing it in one sitting. Perhaps.. slightly sleep deprived.

reviewText:
When I saw Qora in the steam news one day I got pretty exited. This game looked neat, and different than anything I had ever seen before, and it was. The first thing I hear upon opening the game is the beautiful title music. I start to play enjoying the simplicity of the game. Throughout the game only five buttons are actually used, and despite the absence of any dynamic player controls I found this game entertaining.  It only took a couple hours (about 3) but I strongly advise everyone to take their time. Whether it is worth the $10 is completely up to you. (completely worth it if it goes on sale).

Most of the game (exept for parts in the begining where you go left) involves constantly holding D (right arrow default) to walk endlessly to the right (perhaps a little slowly for my taste but this can be overlooked). All actions in the game including the few player interaction moves (jumping, climbing, etc.) are all executed using the spacebar (default) and can only be used when prompted by the game.

There is no doubt that if you get this game it will not be for the direct gameplay which is virtually nonexistant. It will be for:
1. the soundtrack, which is quite good especially that opening theme and comparable to the FEZ soundtrack
2. the scenery, in which some cases you may sit on onescreen for a few minutes just looking at it
3. the plot, the feeling this game causes is impossible to accurately explain

The Plot - (NO spoilers here keep reading)
The plot over all was great. The journey that your charcter embarks on will fill you a sence of awe. It goes at a relatively slow pace but that is how this game is. It keeps you wondering building up with more mystery untill the end, and it turns out it is the single worst ending I have ever seen in a game with such a great ... well everything else. The ending had a ruinous effect on the feeling the rest of the game created. You play through such a mysterious, deep, moving plot and then it is ruined by a very trivial ending in which a very serious game is turned into a big joke.

So here is what I recomend. I would encourage you to get the game as it is truely a great game, but i would actually advise you not to view the ending thereby maintaining that sense of wonder this game will surely cause you to feel.

reviewText:
This game is pretty great! Talked to random people in town and they handed me weaponry, incense, and tacky clothing- and I'm not above being swayed by bribery!

In all seriousness though, the game mostly involves walking, talking, and experiencing the world. There's very little in the way of gameplay, as you generally spend most of your time moving from place to place interacting with other characters, or the environment. So if you like more passive gameplay/storytelling, this one will be worth a shot.

The writing is amazing, for while the plot hasn't sucked me in, the various things characters say more than make up for it, especially early-on. The dude that gave me the machete might've been using me to hide evidence, as he'd recently used it to murder a bunch of kids to feed to his pigs. It's delivered well though, as it's the kind of line you can easily skip over, misinterpret, or miss entirely because you were reading too fast.

The art/music/sound effects fit everything perfectly. It's gorgeous, has great atmosphere, and while it's minimalistic, it's very imaginative.

My only complaint is you use the dpad to walk, and you walk slowly. It helps push the atmospheric nature of everything, but it gets a bit frustrating after a while. Also, interacting with objects is obnoxious (ladders are hard to climb, which is nonsense).

Overall, if you like calm, story driven games, with little to no real gameplay- this one's probably worth picking up. It's fairly short though, and while it has multiple endings- it's probably better on sale.

reviewText:
Playing through Qora is like gazing into a campfire for ages. If you're looking for a game with combat, puzzle-platforming and action, this is not the game for you. Qora is meant to be played slowly, methodically and calmly. After about 30 minutes, I developed a warm, cozy feeling in my stomach and started getting pretty deep introspective thoughts. A game that actually makes you  think , not just blindly do, is a real rarity.
For a pretentious ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• hole like me, Qora is about giving in to a longing to travel, adventure and explore; it's about letting go of apprehension and just going on a journey and finding some sort of peace and satisfaction from getting to the end. Less conceited players may think this to be bull ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.
Qora has some of the most stunning pixel art I've ever seen in a game, which is accompanied by a lovely soundtrack. Some parts of the game were genuinely heart-warming thanks to a combination of the two. The story is brilliant and manages to weave seriousness and witty, unexpected and sometimes pretty grim humour very well. Unfortunately, it can be finished in under 2 hours and the gameplay itself is pretty shallow.
Qora isn't as much a game as an interactive animated film. If you are willing to get lost in it and take in the beautiful visuals and music, Qora will leave you with some interesting ideas and a pleasant, lasting impression. If you think this sounds like your cup of tea, you should absolutely buy it.

reviewText:
So here‚Äôs the thing‚ÄîI don‚Äôt mind short, visual novel and point and click style games‚ÄîI loved To The Moon and Broken Age. So I would, in theory, enjoy a slow paced visually arsty exploration game with minimal player involvement for the experience of it all. However, Qora was a real disappointment for me.

First on the visual elements‚ÄîI found the art style underwhelming. There are some gorgeous 8-bit style games out there. This, in my opinion, wasn‚Äôt one of them. I don‚Äôt know, the advertised screenshots were pretty, but I quickly found the visuals monotonous. Same with the music, there were some pretty themes, but the repetition quickly irritated me. One random positive note for me though was that I found the jumping, stair climbing, and pickaxe swinging animations strangely satisfying. Maybe because it was something new to look at.

The story‚ÄîOh god the writing in this. I think its trying really hard to be edgy and funny, but it just fails so badly that I felt like I was cringing every time I had to read dialogue, and you have to read a fair bit (you have to talk to basically everyone in town in order to get the items you need to continue). Jokes about decapitation, suicide, bestiality, and homophobia were casually tossed about, and I wasn‚Äôt bothered so much as confused‚ÄîI thought this was more a meditation on the meaning of life, not South Park, and they weren‚Äôt even remotely funny, just stupid, which would have been their own redeeming value.

Also, the plotting was weird in my mind, I felt shoehorned into a story I didn‚Äôt particularly care about, with a (mostly) silent protagonist (who won‚Äôt comment on things like the gods talking to him or boulders crashing down and nearly killing him but will note that its kinda odd that there‚Äôs a ghost) and a mystery that not even the other characters in the game seem to care that much about. There seems to be no investment in trying to get the player to care about what‚Äôs happening and why, just assuming that if we continue playing we obviously care about what‚Äôs going to happen next.

Mechanics‚Äîand this is where I basically found my feeling for this game going from frustration to rage. After twenty minutes of playtime, I decided to save and quit and maybe see if I wanted to try it again some other time. Or at least I tried to; the game helpfully informed me that if I left now all my progress on level would be lost. I resigned myself to playing some more, sure that eventually I‚Äôd get to the end of the level and be able to save. Nope. I played over an hour, with every time I tried to quit getting the same message, and no indications of whether or not I had gotten to a new level or if the game had saved. I eventually just gave up and left.

Maybe someday I‚Äôll try again and find out if the game actually saved anywhere or if I‚Äôll have to start over again from the beginning. Maybe. Probably not.

reviewText: Like that sort of made-for-TV epic storytelling, Qora has a moral at its core, but much of its screen time is lost to the writers' sense of humor and whimsy. The path ahead is almost entirely linear, brought to life with beautiful vistas crafted through pixel art and supported by a tranquil soundtrack. But there's very little to actually interact with, so what is there ends up feeling very perfunctory. Every tool, save one, is collected before the adventure starts; there's not even any mystery or problem solving there (though I can't imagine the backtracking involved if you did not take your time and speak to everyone). You're encouraged from the beginning to play slowly, but it's difficult to miss an opportunity permanently and it's impossible to die. There's no stress or tension here. It's all replaced with a soothing calm that permeates the whole experience. With as little input or risk as it requires from the player, Qora could have easily been made as a film, but it'd be a film worth watching. Should you feel inclined to spend the time and money on it, you'll likely walk away happier than you were when you started, as brief and straightforward as the game is.

reviewText:
Qora is absolutely beautiful. The music and visuals are perfect. It's less of a game and more of an interactive story, but it really immerses you in its surreal world and is well worth playing.

The movement of your character is very slow and cannot be sped up. In each screen, you are faced with obstacles which will take not skill or imagination, but time and patience to overcome. At times it can feel eternal, and even get a bit frustrating, but you are driven forward by curiosity ‚Äì what strange and interesting thing will you encounter on the next screen? - as well as a desire to overcome the obstacles and prove your determination. There are countless games out there that test our reflexes or critical thinking skill, but it's rare for a game to test our patience - and to do it well. This game felt like a rare exception.

My only complaint lies with the achievements: in order to get them all, you must play the entire game through twice. I think this was a huge mistake on the part of the developer. This game has no real replay value. There are two endings, but the differences in gameplay between getting one ending and getting the other are minute. Most people will probably get the ‚Äúgood‚Äù ending first, then, noticing they are missing an achievement, realize they have to go back and do the whole thing over again while making mistakes. The second playthrough has all the joy and wonder sucked out of it as you race for the finish to get your final Steam achievement. The game would have been much improved without this.

Despite this one criticism, I still recommend getting the game. It's an experience which you will not regret. The visuals and music alone make it worth your time and money, and the ending will make you think differently about how we view certain aspects of our culture.

reviewText:
Recommended, but with the caveat that this is an extremely linear, slow game with very little interactivity.

You play the part of the new guy in a village nestled in the mountains of an unspecified (but Asian-flavored) country. A little digging ends up with you being able to see into the past and the spirit world, eventually leading you into an ancient temple and weirder places beyond.
You basically move onwards through a linear path*, hitting the appropriate key (up, down, or space) to deal with obstacles. While the game looks like a platformer, there's no skill involved at all and the morose pace can be off-putting (I groaned every time there was a screen with a lot of pits). If you're thorough it'll last you two to three hours, with very little replayability, though it would be unfair to hold it against a game like this.
So that's the negatives, and it's not too bad as long as you know what you're getting into. Other than that, the presentation is excellent, and the pixel art does a great job of depicting varied, interesting locales; combined with the music and the imaginative setting, it makes the (linear) exploration pretty satisfying. The writing is a lot of fun, alternately clever, evocative and goofy; the game takes itself way less seriously than you'd expect.

*: This is not strictly true - at some points there are short alternate routes or backtracking elements to find optional collectibles, which you need all of to get the true" ending."

reviewText:
Summary
If you enjoy linear, slow-paced adventure games with little in the way of gameplay mechanics, this is the title for you.

Visuals and audio
I‚Äôm getting a little tired of the endless barrage of pixel-based titles, so the less said on this point the better.
I‚Äôve seen a few people lauding the game‚Äôs soundtrack (which you can also purchase for a small fee), but I didn‚Äôt find it anything special. Take any lounge music track and slow it down to half speed. Done.

Gameplay
This is what lets the game down and sapped all my incentive to play. In the absence of a jump key or the ability to run, you‚Äôre left slowly scrolling from left to right along a completely linear path. In fact, even when moving up and down objects, the animations are painfully unhurried. Thankfully, in aside from the walking simulator elements, there are opportunities to interact with the environment. Unfortunately, these are primarily limited to two functions: chopping down grass that blocks your path, and breaking rocks that block your path.

The pace of the game is slow, and if that‚Äôs your bag, you‚Äôll probably enjoy it. For me, I‚Äôd much prefer to run quickly by areas in which zero new gameplay is occurring, especially if backtracking previously explored areas.

Narrative
Unfortunately, the leisurely, repetitive and unengaging nature of the gameplay was such that I became bored and impatient before I had the opportunity to experience much of the narrative.

Of the sections I did persevere with and play through, it looks as though the central storyline could progress somewhere interesting, pursuing the ability to connect with a spirit world.

Aside from the main narrative of the game, the dialogue with NPCs left much to be desired. The writers consciously attempted to write the NPC dialogue as humorous, but failed rather miserably and came across as trying far too hard in this respect. In fact, the strained ‚Äòzany‚Äô nature of the dialogue was such that I soon gave up bothering to talk to NPCs.

reviewText: The very definition of a walking-simulator. You hold a button to move from left to right, pressing the context-sensitive action button whenever you hit an obstacle (jump, cut grass, break stone, etc.). Half of these telepathy sequences have no bearing on the story whatsoever, and show you random animations that will just make you scratch your head. The other half of these sequences are story-related, showing you snippets from the journey of an ancient empress whose footsteps you are following.\n\nSometimes I am in the mood for a lazy experience where I do not have to do much, but it is hard to recommend Qora because I found the story (and ending) very underwhelming.

reviewText:
Pros
+Beautiful artwork
+Great soundtrack
+Funny, but not to the point of distracting from the story

Cons
-Walking is slow
-Really slow
-Everything is slow
-Slow
-Short, but slow

Qora is basically a sidescrolling walking simulator. That's not necessarily bad, but you need to know that going in. It tells an interesting story and has great scenery, but it does all that at a very slow pace. Despite this sluggishness it only takes about an hour and a half to finish the game. That said, the entire hour and a half is beautiful, and has excellent music. Think of it as an hour and a half 8-bit Yes album cover/Roger Dean illustration.
$10 is about the right price if you're into this kind of thing, but if you're not really sure wait for a sale.

(Oh, and heads up, you have to play all the way through twice to get all the achievements and both endings)

I just want to say first and foremost this game is very well detailed, interesting and for the most part, witty and insightful, however as with most games there's a lot of stuff that is needed to be fixed for the next game. But first I just want to say that the dialouge is fresh as I said for the most part. The sound track and visuals too are just beautiful, the atmosphere is calming and just on that alone this game does it for me. However as much as I love this game, there are faults to be had here and I shall name a few. I shall try to not spoil anything of course in this review

Problem        Description                Drawn out content:        Though playing this was fun at times especially at certain sections it seems the level deisng inherinetly is made to only waste your time. For example there's grass and rocks you absolutely have to mine to go further into the game. However they are used almost too often in the game and without significant breaks in between, not only that but it takes time, even a small amount fo time, to clear them out. Now this isnt a proiblem if it was only a few sections and you didnt have to waste so much time per cutting/mining them out. But I feel the balance of this is offset a lot to jsut draw out the gameplay                Repatitive content        Now this isnt neccasarily as big as the drawn out content because this sorta plays into that problem a bit more but I beleive its a point worth bringing up. Firstly the doors, whilst I eventually saw them as a summery for what I had previously done I found them initially and even when I saw them as summeries, a bit repatitive. The same basic thing was being said over and over and as much as the door opening initially was awe-inspiring, the 6th+ time? Not so much                Cliched        Now this could potentually be a problem but it depends on person to person, it could also be because of the simple fact this game usually likes to have a decent amount of references in this game. reviewText:
Qora is a game I think everyone likes exploration games should own. It's linear, it's relaxing, and it has an awesome soundtrack.

So, I don't exactly know how to compress my feelings about qora at all. I guess I'll start by the graphics. The graphics design was extremely beautiful. Same goes for the designs, the areas are all extremely well made. Most of them are surreal and unique, and even the plain ones still feel really good. It had a good storyline, I was not expecting the ending at all. Seeing that the ghost was the empress and the empress was qora were both suprising. The soundtrack was pretty good. The music really went well with each location. When it was a dark situation, there was silent eerie soundtrack. When you were in a beautiful area, there was calm or upbeat music. I think you get what I mean.
It has a good athmosphere, there are some very creepy scenes, especially the scene with the hidden bunker. It also has two endings, and multiple ends are always nice! It does leave some questions in your head though. What are the white masked guys? Aliens? Did the deities give anyone else gifts when they moved in, and did they have to go through all that too?

Now, I don't recommend it for everyone. There isn't really much to do in it. There is a lot of exploration, but no puzzles, action sequences or deaths in this case. It's linear, and most of the time you are just heading right. There are some scenes where you have to wake up beasts, break rocks or do a little platforming, but most of the time it's just a game about exploring scenery. If you don't like games like that, then you should probably not buy this. Other than that, it's a pretty great game.

Also, love the credits theme. The quotes people wrote are pretty silly, you guys all make me laugh :3

Sorry for the short review, but like I said, there isn't much to say about qora other than the things I have mentioned.

There is something that works really well in Qora: despite the extremely mundane gameplay, the game strongly feels like a journey. Maybe not an epic one, but a journey none the less in a stranger and stranger land. I think that works because of the pacing, the mundane, a certain sense of wonder and the quantity of content. I mean when I first thought 'I sure travelled a long way' I was maybe half way through the game.

Sadly, it feels the creator was not very confident in the 'contemplative initiatic quest' quality of his game and decided to spice it up with a humorous tone that feels out of place. Worse, the grand finale is a meta humor fest that feels like a kick in the nuts. A bit as if the 'proper' ending of Silent Hill 2 was the dog ending...

I am all for humor and meta, but not when they feel like the creator used them as escape plan. Sometimes you have to dare to tell a story.

reviewText: First things first. I like this game, its not overly exciting, nor does it have interesting characters or a massive in-depth story. Additionally, this is an extremely casual game, similar Flower, or Journey in feel. What it lacks in interesting gameplay it makes up for with beautiful, relaxing music and magnificent scenery. I admit, however that the music does tend to drone on a bit, even still I found it pleasent to listen to. The whole beautiful pixel art scenic background thing thats popular among many indie developers may seem overdone to some, but i find to be a creative way to immerse the player in the world. all in all I'd give this game an 8/10.
